column1: Priego de Córdoba is a town and municipality of Spain located in the autonomous community of Andalusia. It lies on the southeasternmost end of the province of Córdoba
column2: near the headwater of the Guadajoz
column3: and on the northern slope of the Sierra de Priego. The population in 2015 was 22

column1: == History ==

Priego is a village found on the Ruta del Califato (trade route of the Caliphate). It is called “City of the water” because of the many springs and "Jewel of the Baroque Native of Córdoba” for the multitude of its Baroque-style constructions. It has been referred to as “the lock and key to the Kingdom of Granada”.The oldest section of Priego is its Barrio de la Villa. It is bordered on one side by the town's natural fortress
column2: a high cliff. The alleys that wind through this part of the town are Moorish in style
column3: decorated proudly by the populace with flower pots and religious icons. Some homes retain the ancient tunnel system that went from their cellars (bodegas) to the castle.

column1: Some of the best examples of the Spanish Baroque are found in the numerous churches in Priego. The oldest church was built in the 13th century and subsequently restored; it has a fine chapel. There are ruins (under restoration as of 2006) of a castle having been a fortified city of the Moors (with the Hispano-Arabic name Baguh)
column2: eventually captured by the Christians under Ferdinand III in 1225
column4: and finally retaken in 1340 by Alfonso XI.

column1: == Economy ==
Its economy is based on agricultural products
column2: mainly olive oil and cereals. The olive oil from Priego has been given its own denominational label. The olive oils have recently garnered many of the most prestigious prizes in international competitions."Venta del Barón" is the best olive oil in the world since 2014 2015 and 2016

column1: == Culture ==
The religious brotherhoods of Priego have a long history
column2: some dating back to before the 16th century. The traditional displays of these brotherhoods in the religious processions of Holy Week (Semana Santa) are renowned for their grandeur and beauty.

column1: The procession on Holy Thursday (Jueves Santo) of the Brotherhood of the Column (Jesus de la Columna)
column2: which is the oldest and most prestigious of the town's brotherhoods
column3: and on Holy Friday (Viernes Santo) the Brotherhood of the Nazarenos
column4: in which the procession is of a hand carried float with Christ carrying the cross.

column1: The Nazareno is carried from a church in the center of Priego to a mountain top that overlooks Priego known as the Calavario. Once there a priest comes out of the hermitage there and delivers a benediction. The population holds up pastries in the form of roosters or pigs
column2: with a hard boiled egg in the center
column3: known as 'hornazos'. After the benediction it is considered good luck for the coming year to eat the pastry.
